Posts.Content: Hi Sarah! It is an almost impossible decision to make, isn't it? I was in exactly the same position as you but mine was only 3mm lurking amongst the DCIS picked up on a routine mammogram and grade 3. Two lumpectomies to get clear margins and no node involvement. It's also Her2 positive but they won't give you Herceptin unless you have a course of chemo first. I've had 4 rounds of FEC and curse the side-effects daily. 4 weeks of radiotherapy then 18 x herceptin ti look forward to :-) BUT I know I will have done everything possible to kick the little bugger into touch and that if there are any dodgy cells still lurking somewhere, their days are numbered. It'll be 18 months of treatment, but I consider it worth it for even just an extra 2% peace of mind. I don't do 'what if''. Good luck with your journey on this scary rollercoaster!
Posts.Title: How much should stats play a part in the decision to have chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Joanne I'm just a few months ahead of you in this very scary journey. All that I can add to the excellent advice already offered is: 'Normal' as you once understood it doesn't exist anymore - the rules will change every day so rather than try to fight it, go along for the ride. Take a notebook with you when you see any of the medical team, especially the specialist nurse. Ask plenty of questions and write down the replies. You will be bombarded by so much info, you will never remember everything. Hope everything goes well xx

Posts.Title: Time between lumpectomy and chemo?

Posts.Content: Hello all! I began this journey in January when I had a recall on a routine mammogram. Lumpectomy on February 19th including 5 lymph glands followed by a re-excision on March 14th to get clear margins.  Lymph glands clear and 2 small areas of Grade 3 removed which tested positive for Herceptin. After my second 2-week check up (March 26th) I was told I would be having chemo & herceptin to 'mop up' anything they haven't found plus 20 doses of radiotherapy. An appointment would be made with the oncologist within a couple of weeks and that chemo would begin soon after. The appointment turned out to be 6 weeks after surgery because of staff shortages. The oncologist ordered all the tests and scans to make sure I was fit enough for the chemo/herceptin and at my appointment today, (May 12th) she confirmed it will all go ahead as planned. Now I have to wait until I have a chemotherapy group pre-assessment on the May 21st to find out when chemo will start. That will be at least 11 weeks from the second lumpectomy. Is this too long to wait or am I just too impatient to get things started?

Posts.Content: Hi all you lovely people. Hope you are enjoying this summery (!!) Bank Holiday weekend. It's pouring down here :-( Once again I seem to be working my way down the list of possible side-effects of this delightful course of treatment. The story so far - Calf pains a couple of weeks ago on day 6 of 4th round of FEC rang warning bells of DVT and headed off to A&E. Scans showed no sign of a clot and all looked well. No other diagnosis was offered. The crampy/sore/achy leg slowly improved over the next couple of days and I've been wearing my 'Nora Batty' stockings :-) Had 5th dose of FEC on Tuesday and today I can barely walk. Pain is now from the back of my thigh, down through the calf and into my foot. Assuming it's still not DVT, what does anyone think? Cramp? Cellulitis? Phlebitis? (The veins in my arm are now totally flea'd up) Exercise or rest? Painkillers or not? Anyone else had anything similar?
Posts.Title: Leg Pain - FEC chemo - cause?

Posts.Content: Woohooo...had first dose of FEC yesterday with just 24 hours notice - someone was supposed to have phoned me apparently - but luckily I had a pre-assessment on Wednesday. Touch wood, only the hang-over from hell to worry about so far. Can I take painkillers? I remember being advised not to take paracetemol in case it masks a fever. 5 different anti-sickness drugs seem to be working well but my beloved cup of tea tastes absolutely foul :-( Hey ho. Resting up now so that I can sneak into next weekend's festival even if I have to stay in the campervan, listening to the music through the window. Hope you're all feeling hunky dory-ish on this grey morning xx

Posts.Content: I'm halfway through FEC and find that it's taking longer to recover from the side-effects each time. The tiredness seems to be cumulative and I'm finding it more difficult to get going each morning. Do I push myself to be as 'normal' as possible or do I take the opportunity to put my feet up and ignore the hoovering/mowing the lawn/cleaning the loo? Luckily my ability to stress-out seems to have disappeared too :-) How do you all manage to motivate yourselves?

Posts.Content: Did you get those quotes from my mother????? :-) I don't have metastatic breast cancer and I can't begin to imagine how difficult it is to live with but I find that people I talk to are probably as scared as I am about the whole thing. This leads them to say a) the first thing that pops into their head or b) something they think will comfort me or c) something they think might actually be useful. The way I look at it - it's not their fault I have cancer and at least they haven't crossed the road to avoid speaking to me. I just smile, nod and talk about something else :-)

Posts.Title: mobile phone and breast cancer

Posts.Content: I've had frozen shoulder x2 and I can confirm it is the most painful and debilitating condition. As previously said, acupuncture can help. I was lucky to find my local NHS physios were trained in acupuncture so it's worth asking your GP. Cold packs wrapped in a tea towel also provide relief. The exercises that I was given when I had my lumpectomy are very similar to those given for frozen shoulder too. A tennis ball in a long sock rolled between your back and a wall feels good if not excruciatingly painful. Bizarre! The 'normal' scenario is that it takes 18 months to resolve - 6 months freezing, 6 months frozen and 6 months defrosting. Arm movement becomes increasingly restricted especially above the head and behind the back. Hope that helps xx
